title: R46361
content: The report provides an overview of the FY2020 Defense Appropriations Act (P.L. 116-93) and summarizes the budgetary context and major components of the Trump Administration's budget request. The Trump Administration requested $750.0 billion for national defense activities, with $718.3 billion allocated for the military activities of the Department of Defense. The FY2020 Defense Appropriations Act allocated $718.3 billion for the military activities of the Department of Defense, with the remaining budget for defense-related activities of other agencies. The bill does not include funding for military construction, family housing, or the TRICARE for Life program. The FY2020 Defense Appropriations Act allocated $718.3 billion for military activities, excluding funding for military construction, family housing, and the TRICARE for Life program. The total DOD budget is $687.8 billion, $2.86 billion less than President Trump's request. Since 2001, DOD has structured its budget to distinguish between post-9/11 activities and base budget costs. Since 2001, the DOD has allocated funds for post-9/11 activities separate from its base budget. The non-base budget funds are designated for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) and are exempt from spending caps set by the Budget Control Act of 2011. The FY2020 defense budget request was $576.2 billion, with additional funds allocated for emergency requirements like storm damage remediation. The FY2020 defense budget request included $576.2 billion for the base budget and an additional $97.9 billion designated as OCO funding to avoid exceeding spending caps. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2019 raised the defense spending cap to $666.5 billion, rendering the issue moot. The FY2020 defense appropriations bill was enacted on August 2, 2019, raising the defense spending cap to $666.5 billion. The House and Senate each reported separate versions of the bill, with a compromise version agreed upon by House and Senate negotiators and incorporated into another bill (H.R. 1158). The FY2020 defense appropriations bill, H.R. 1158, was passed by both chambers without a formal conference report. After the 9/11 attacks, U.S. national security policy shifted to focus on countering terrorism and insurgencies in the Middle East, while also addressing North Korean and Iranian nuclear programs. The Trump Administration's National Security Strategy and National Defense Strategy focus on great power competition with China and Russia, blurring lines between conventional and irregular conflict, and collaborating with non-state proxies. The 2018 National Defense Strategy reorients U.S. national security towards great power competition with China and Russia, emphasizing the need to bolster the competitive advantage of U.S. forces. This shift acknowledges the erosion of U.S. military capabilities vis-à-vis Chinese and Russian threats, requiring a new approach to achieving military objectives. The Trump Administration's strategic orientation, as outlined in the National Security Strategy (NSS) and National Defense Strategy (NDS), prioritizes countering China and Russia over violent extremist organizations. This "2+3" strategy focuses on addressing two primary challenges (China and Russia) and three additional challenges (North Korea, Iran, and terrorist groups).
